Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evaluating Retreat in the Amundsen Sea Embayment: Assessing Controlling Processes, Uncertainties, and Projections
Award.AbstractNarration:
Accurate reconstructions and predictions of glacier movement on timescales of human interest require a better understanding of available observations and the ability to model the key processes that govern ice flow. The fact that many of these processes are interconnected, are loosely constrained by data, and involve not only the ice, but also the atmosphere, ocean, and solid Earth, makes this a challenging endeavor, but one that is essential for Earth-system modeling and the resulting climate and sea-level forecasts that are provided to policymakers worldwide. Based on the amount of ice present in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet and its ability to flow and/or melt into the ocean, its complete collapse would result in a global sea-level rise of 3.3 to 5 meters, making its stability and rate of change scientific questions of global societal significance. Whether or not a collapse eventually occurs, a better understanding of the potential West Antarctic contribution to sea level over the coming decades and centuries is necessary when considering the fate of coastal population centers. Recent observations of the Amundsen Sea Embayment of West Antarctica indicate that it is experiencing faster mass loss than any other region of the continent. At present, the long-term stability of this embayment is unknown, with both theory and observations suggesting that collapse is possible. This study is focused on this critical region. We will test an ice-sheet model against existing observations, improve treatment of key processes in the model, and make projections with uncertainty assessments.

This is a three-year modeling study using the open-source Ice Sheet System Model in coordination with other models to improve projections of future sea-level change. Project goals are to:
1. hindcast the past two-to-three decades of evolution of the Amundsen Sea Embayment sector to determine controlling processes, incorporate and test parameterizations, and assess and improve model initialization, spinup, and performance;
2. improve the model by utilizing sensitivity studies with regional process-oriented models to create numerically efficient parameterizations for key sub-grid-scale processes;
3. project a range of likely evolutions of the Amundsen Sea Embayment sector and their respective contributions to sea level in the next several centuries;
4. attribute sources of errors in the hindcast and provide an assessment of the uncertainties in the projections, including a range of likely outcomes given various forcings and inclusion or omission of physical processes in the model.
At present, the long-term stability of the Amundsen Sea Embayment is unknown, with both theory (the "marine ice sheet instability hypothesis") and observations (rapid thinning and grounding-line retreat approaching regions where the bed deepens inland) suggesting that collapse is possible. But incompletely understood physical processes (e.g., basal hydrology, rheology, and sliding; tidal effects; ice-ocean interaction along the shelf and within the grounding zone) and lack of resolution in basal topography datasets making the ultimate outcome uncertain. Thus, there is a pressing need for high-resolution simulations of this region that include numerical representations of controlling physical processes (many of which are applicable elsewhere) within a higher-order ice-sheet model capable of assimilating recent observations and providing uncertainty analyses associated with model and data limitations. By focusing on the Amundsen Sea Embayment as a connected region across the 10-10,000-meter scales using a hierarchy of one, two, and three-dimensional models along with the sensitivity analysis tools built into the Ice Sheet System Model, this project aims to produce (1) the most reliable results to date when compared with studies that consider only one ice stream or the entire ice sheet and (2) estimates of differing dynamic responses arising from errors in data, model parameterizations, and forcings. Given the uncertainties, the project will produce a range of predictions with characteristic trends that can be recognized within future observational data sets. As new data become available, some predicted rates of change could be culled from the predictive paths generated by this study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Accurate reconstructions and predictions of glacier movement on timescales of human interest require a better understanding of available observations and the ability to model the key processes that govern ice flow.  Many of these processes are interconnected, are loosely constrained by data, and involve not only the ice, but also the atmosphere, ocean, and solid Earth, making this a challenging endeavor that is essential for Earth-system modeling and the resulting climate and sea-level forecasts that are provided to policymakers worldwide. Based on the amount of ice present in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet and its ability to flow and/or melt into the ocean, its complete collapse would result in a global sea-level rise of 3.3 to 5 meters, making its stability and rate of change scientific questions of global societal significance. 

 

Recent observations of the Amundsen Sea Embayment (ASE) of West Antarctica indicate that it is experiencing faster mass loss than any other region of the continent.  At present, the long-term stability of this embayment is unknown, with both theory and observations suggesting that collapse is possible.  This study focused on this critical region as well as processes governing changes in outlet glacier flow. It led to improved physical understanding and future data-collection strategies. The project included five different ice-flow models and six investigators (three early career, one underrepresented) across four institutions, three graduate students (one underrepresented), and two undergraduates (one double minority).  At Penn State, in addition to co-authoring twenty-two publications, seventy-seven professional and outreach presentations, and public engagement efforts, a VR exhibit that will interactively display results from select simulations is underway in our EMS museum.     

 

Almost all glaciers and ice streams flow along valleys, but Thwaites Glacier (TG) is like some historical ice flow in going across the dominant topography.  We addressed the controlling processes associated with this flow across topography through geophysical and numerical modeling studies, which together indicate that remotely constraining basal properties and their origin is both doable and critical to future projections of ice flow in the ASE.  

 

In the event that TG loses its resistance to rapid flow, whether by removal of its remaining floating ice shelf (e.g., through ocean melting or calving icebergs) which provides drag particularly on its eastern side and/or by widening of the fast-flowing inland regions (e.g., through basal lubrication), the overall flow response depends strongly on the basal properties and tends towards collapse of Thwaites within a few centuries, with the rate determined by the poorly-constrained bed conditions as well as the timing of the processes that ultimately reduce the flow resistance.

 

Through observations and modeling, unfortunately we found that a period of several years of ocean cooling in Pine Island Bay only temporarily slowed the flow of Pine Island Glacier's floating ice shelf and did little to slow its retreat.

 

As far as potential future forcings, perhaps the fastest way to evacuate ice from the ASE is through ice-cliff failure. We determined that sufficiently tall ice cliffs will ultimately fail by slumping (much like on hillslopes) followed by buoyancy-driven calving.  The processes associated with cliff failure are active now for the highest cliffs in the warmer Greenland and Antarctic Peninsula Ice Sheets, and could occur much faster if TG loses its ice shelf and retreats into the deep interior basins, generating cliffs taller than any now observed. 

 

One possible way to slow down this catastrophic failure mode is to clog the outlet to the open ocean by mixing sea ice with icebergs. A continuum model of this so-called ice melange was developed and applied to drastic retreat episodes of the Antarctic Ice Sheet. The main conclusion is that melange in Antarctica does little to slow retreat and ice collapse, due to the much wider basins in Antarctica compared to the much narrower Greenland fjords.

 

We also presented different statistical techniques that can be used to assess ice-flow response to external forcings. In one study, we learned that data collection focused on down-glacier conditions is extremely valuable in predicting overall outlet glacier flow, but that observations of time-varying events elsewhere is also critical for improving our knowledge of the basal conditions that control the rate and extent of the outlet glacier evolution.  In three other studies, we detailed how to and why gaining a regional view of basal properties is essential.    

 

Finally, geologic setting also impacts ice flow through heat flowing up from the rocks below.  Past fluctuations of the Greenland ice sheet and its ongoing shrinkage have changed stresses in the underlying rocks, which we found may have aided in bringing melted rock upward, thereby increasing heat flow to the base of the ice. With loading and unloading in West Antarctica, the heat flow in the ASE may have also been impacted in ways that help promote wide-spread lubrication at the ice-bed interface.
